author: Matt Watts
title: Homeless couple to marry after 'unbelievably kind' strangers arrange wedding for them
text:
Thursday 16 February 2017 09:10 GMT Click to followThe Evening Standard Better life: Chris Groombridge and fiancée Kirsty Richardson hope for a home soon Alex Lentati 
A homeless couple are to marry thanks to the “unbelievable kindness” of strangers who arranged a wedding for them after finding them sleeping rough in south-west London. 
Chris Groombridge, 37, and Kirsty Richardson, 29, were engaged and living together in Coventry but lost their jobs as concert and festival stewards and later their home. 
They have been sleeping rough in the capital since May last year, living in a tent in a park in Kingston over the winter. 
In November, they met an outreach group from Kingsgate Church in Kingston who struck up a bond with them and resolved to put on a wedding for them for free. 
“It’s unbelievably kind, the nicest thing anyone has ever done for us,” said Mr Groombridge. “We got engaged but then we ended up on the streets, but we love each other and still wanted so much to get married. Things are very hard, but we have each other. 
“For the wedding to be happening now is just amazing and the kindness and faith in us is an inspiration for us to work hard to improve our situation.” 
The wedding, which will cost about £2,000, has been funded through cash donations and people offering their services for free. The church has rented suits for the groom and groomsmen, bought Miss Richardson a wedding gown and found dresses for her bridesmaids. There will also be a three-night honeymoon at a hotel. 
The ceremony will be held at the church on Friday. Paul Ryan, 55, who runs the outreach group, said: “We were inspired by their love for each other.” Miss Richardson said: “I dreamed of us getting married but I didn’t imagine it would be like this.” 
The church is also trying to find a flat for the couple and asked for donations to help at justgiving.com/crowdfunding/chris-kirsty-wedding More about:
